Comment: Marin plays a conservative French defense.
Marin plays a conservative French defense.
Book.
The standard response, and a must.
Solid. 3 P-K5 locks the center but without development White will be hard-pressed to hold it.
Tempting yates to play 4 P-K5.
Yates instead continues his development.
Practically forced. The only other choice was 4... Q-Q2 to avoid losing the pinned Knight by...
...this move, which has now been adequately prepared.
With the more cramped position, Marin naturally wishes to whittle down the wood. This move forces the exchange of at least one pair of minor pieces.
Yates elects to trade Bishops.
Completing the exchange.
Attacking the weakened King-side at once.
Marin tucks his King into what he *thinks* is a safe spot...
Threatening to win a Pawn by exchanging on K4, so...
...Marin preemptively exchanges off the Knight himself.
Completing the trade.
With Yates having a K-side spatial advantage, Marin wishes to gain space on the Q-side as a counterbalance.
Developing with a hidden threat. The proper defence is 10... P-KN3, cutting off the Bishop's diagonal.
Marin overlooks the threat, and is blindsided by...

...this thunderbolt from heaven! Marin resigns at once. If 11... KxB 12 Q-R5 ch K-N1 13 N-N5, and the only way to stop mate is 13... QxN 14 QxQ leaving Marin with a hopeless disadvantage in material. [13... R-Q1 14 Q-R7 ch K-B1 15 Q-R8 mate.] And 11... K-R1 12 Q-R5 sets up a devastating discovered check that cannot be prevented.
